segments.text: Thank you, Arnold.
I feel very honored to be in your company, and you're all members of a profession which I really appreciate.
with appreciated libraries in two roles.

So you're talking about one role of libraries, appreciated libraries in two roles, one of repositories of knowledge, but also throughout all of my life there's really places in which to access that knowledge, places where you go in and there's a feeling of that.
academic values and just studying for whatever that tradition of knowledge bring back so far.
to have in a building.
So I don't know if people have asked what happens to institutions or the library or the university in the electronic age.

It may be that the two pieces get separated but I hope as well as preserving all the knowledge out there that somehow buildings and the places and that feeling of how important this is preserved as well.

So, I will, I don't know, I feel pretty, you know, you are alexis in this, so I feel at my own, I come with questions rather than answers, so I'd like to spend an hour just asking you questions on how you're going to spell forward.
But I can't.
But first of all, I think I'd better put forward a framework for a little while, and then we can do a beautiful question and answer at the end.
Let me see where I'm coming from about why I felt it was really important and exciting to put together the World Wide Web in the first place briefly.

And then try to throw some ideas, perhaps responses to some of the questions I think we all have about what we're going to do about preserving the collecting and preserving digital information in the future.
First of all, the web
conceptually, hopefully, about the web is that unlike the things you talked to on the internet beforehand, it's an abstract space.
It is just a space of information.
There really were two dreams originally behind it.
And even that original program in Fire Within One Everything had, it talked about one aspect of it, and I think the dream was also there, and that means the power of the back of us is a manual.
The first reason is that the outside source of information is the way you communicate.
As human beings, we communicate, well, we think of communication as a model of talking to each other on telephones.
So it's back in a huge amount of our communication.
And the communication that really counts, and the communication that you've been out at, is largely when we build something together.
When there is a piece of information which we work on together, then our little primitive
which works on the plans for the new wings, or a group of people putting together a newspaper, together create something.
As they do that, they end up building a little culture within themselves, because they've received terms in a particular way.
In doing that, they build little barriers between them and the rest of the world.
They create a space of information.
That information, the common information they have,
is the way they communicate.
And that's it.
This model of communication, for me, it worked very well when I was working at CERN, the particle physics lab, where everybody was trying to build things.
Often the physicists, the high-energy physicists, are spread across the world, but they can't have very many accelerators because they're rather expensive.
So they went to, they would all meet, for example, at Geneva at CERN, where there's some big accelerators.
And when they meet, they bring together all the pieces of huge tracts
or in their head with its software and they try to make it fit together.
So all this building together of a common idea about how something very, very large and completely new was going to be made happened across the internet much.

And it had all the problems that you see in general in large cultures, forming subcultures, whenever you form a subcultures you form a little barrier around the people, you have information, you have new terms, you have an information barrier,
When that group tries to sell its ideas to the larger group, that has to break out.
You see all these things which are on a large scale, you see in politics and war, on a national scale, small scale and families.
All this will be modelled by groups of people who are all connected on the net.
So, as a substrate as part of the world, the idea of the microcosm community, which was a microcosm
of the world of health and health.
These are all people who happen to have all the money and the information to get notifications on their desks.
So even before PCs and Macintoshes were on everybody else's desks, these people had value notifications so they could run web around us.
Part one of the dream was communication through a universal space information.
I think universal, I hope I'll say universal a lot of times because I want that to speak.
The whole point about the web is it is very universal.
If anything is important, you should have a URL to be on the web.
And if you want that, then you can't offer very much help.
So this web has got to be a very accommodating, minimally constraining way.
The design is supposed to be minimally constraining.
It will let absolutely anything to be in there.
It shouldn't be specific to culture.
It shouldn't be specific to particular languages.
It shouldn't be specific to particular sorts of information.
A lot of people have said, why don't you get rid of all the junk?
And I guess you'll spend the rest of the day talking about the question of how to tell what's jacked or what isn't jacked.

And I'll see it very simply, but in fact, it's very important that you should be able to have the scribble circle on the back of an envelope for a social equivalent, on the way, because it may in fact be part of the train of thought, train of reference, which leads to bigger and bigger things.
And you may one day want to trace the design of the bridge back to that envelope.
So the universality, in fact, of the web is something which the World Wide Web Consortium spent a lot of its time defending.
As each piece of design comes out from a new protocol or a new data format or something, we look at it and say, this could be training somehow.
Will this only work for very polished works?
Or will it only work for scruffy notes?
Will it only work for ASCII?
When we look around, there will be very many dimensions along which information varies.
One of the interesting directions along which information varies takes us to the second part of the dream.
Some of the information out there, a lot of the stuff that I just don't like, is designed for people, like people.
When you look at the, when you look at some poetry, it really is a brain-to-brain thing.
Poetry is difficult to analyze with a computer, and it, in fact, analyzes the poetry in a way
a tool kind of takes something away from it.
The whole thing is very much of a direct experience from one person going to another person's mind.
And there's a lot of stuff out there in libraries and on the web which is really designed personally by computer.
So on the web you will find a lot of information about stock prices and you will find a lot of information about weather.
But it's very difficult in fact to access that with a computer.
It's all designed, the medium at the moment is very much designed for people.
And when it's the person-to-person communication medium, the idea was that the computers and the networks should get out of the way.

The idea that computers should fit up in some way that you would impress them with the new operating system they had, and the new network connectivity they had, and the new application that they had, is really good, is very kind of productive.
When it comes to human being communicating with another human being, human being, the job of a computer is to get out of the way.
But then, what happened to that original idea of computers,
When my parents started working on in the fifties, they thought that they could help us solve all of the problems.
The computers have now vanished, and they're just part of the infrastructure.
They're just carrying the ditch around.
In fact, they're bringing the problems to us more and more rapidly.
We can get problems, 500 problems a day in our inbox, and they're not helping solve any of them, really.

So, dream two would just imagine we had an organization, suppose we took something like this, or suppose we took something like this, the system of libraries, or we took a lot of universities, and everybody working in that organization was doing everything with the web, because we've got our tools so intuitive that whenever you create something, whenever you note something down, you note it on some little bit of magic paper, which makes it immediately, which captures it immediately.
And not only that, when you make a reference, you don't just refer to Joe's paper, because Joe's in the room, somehow magically you manage to get a link.
So that all that structure is captured.

Supposing we could really take all of the humans into working in an organization, capture it on the web, then wouldn't it be really interesting, putting back the geek hat to write a program to run over that stuff and analyze it?
Wouldn't it be interesting to find out
how people really are grouped together in our organization.
I know the management said that we're in these divisions.
I know for the first year or two of the web business, I had one convert, Robert Caillou, he was in a different division.
We worked together on this project even though it was seven minutes walk between our offices because we were able to be far apart from the division.
I wonder how many people are like that.
And then wouldn't it be interesting to look at all the projects that are in their interrelationships and find out who actually
within the situations of working on no projects which are actually used by other projects which are actually critical to the famous nation.
How many people?
And who had written software which was described by no documents at all?
That would tell us some of the things about the structure of organization and maybe help us move to that magic sort of self-managing team.
So second part is computers coming back in and helping us analyze the information and play with us.
And there are a variety of services as agents.
At the moment, this is not working.
But at the end of this talk, I'll get back to the future, which I think it will work largely.
Although I say it's not working because really the only computer agent that most people come up with perhaps their email filters is one, but it's a search engine.
So if you want to do something very straightforward, like you want to look for a yellow car for sale in Massachusetts,
You go to your fake search engine of your type, your choice, and you type in, I want to buy a yellow car in Massachusetts.
I want to try it.
No, you've tried it.
You get back a whole other junk.
And the problem is, of course, that the computer doesn't have it.
When it read the page which somebody put up very close to you, for sale, Primrose Honda, right?
Didn't use the word yellow, didn't use the word car.
Good run up, free to go home.
It may not even use the word for sale.

There's nothing the computer can do, because the computer program can't, unless you believe the artificial intelligence in the natural language, which I'm not going to rely on, the computer can't understand that.
Which is funny, because a lot of that weather and a lot of the stock prices all came from databases and had a very, very well-defined form.
But if you write a program to try and access those databases through the web, it's really, really hairy.
So the second part of the web is, in fact, this extreme web where there is data on the web which has a very well-written meaning.
And so the two dreams were communication in one.
And secondly, it causes all this information that becomes available to computers, so we could actually use computers to analyze it.
Now, I should stop talking about those dreams.
I could talk a lot about the state of the web at the moment.
about the technical protocols and the changes we expect to happen.
I talked a lot about the social questions, like privacy, which we're very concerned with, encryption.
There are all sorts of areas in which we could get them to get a choreographed discussion.
But the topic of the day is preservation.
And I must say, this is really, really important to a lot of people.
It may be that one of the things Web of Standards has made it very
more directly clearly apparent to other people than it was before.
It's personally important to me.
Every time I pick up my digital camera and I get another camera, I'm very concerned that I shouldn't lose it.
And I'm very concerned that I can catalog it, I can find it afterwards, I can rate it.
And every time I get rid of an old computer and buy a new one, I try to take the entire content to the original version, and take it in one corner with a huge new space of the new machine.
And leave it there, hopefully.
And ever since the last 10 years, I've been finding everything by date, although I don't have to move things around.
But still, I wonder what's going to, in the long term, I find all the people I work with that do this as well, the team.
So that means that everything we talk about is on the web.
So there's tremendous potential and a really great fear.
At one point, we don't only keep it on the web, but it's a text file.
We use configuration control to keep track of every change to it.
At one point, we lost part of the repository for a few months.
We couldn't track the changes to documents.
And that, I thought, was a terrible, terrible loss.
We couldn't go back.
In that period of time, all the discussions, we couldn't track how a document got from here to here, edit by either, which was a very big chance.
And even though the website was mirrored on six different sites on different continents, that repository was only in one place.
So this preservation is very, very, it's, to me, a very, very immediate thing.
And I think there must be people all over the place who are thinking about exactly the same problems as you look like.
I think they may be waiting for you to tell in which direction to go.
So you may have some more responsibilities here.
A lot of questions that people ask me is about how to select, whether they are librarians or not.
How do we select the junk?
How do we select all things to keep?
We have very, very well-established institutions which have very, very complex and long-standing methods of collecting them.
So we have a system of academic journals, for example.
And generally, librarians, libraries have gone, have fallen into that for a couple of dollars.
We've lost hundreds of money.
And now, this is being threatened for all of us.
There are these online repositories of high-engine physics information.
In fact, some of the early ones raised a lot of questions about whether the journals have been cut out completely.

good people but the physicists were concerned that it took them 18 months to get their latest results out if they used the journal system or they started sidetracking it and using words loud and a rather interesting informal system of peer review and corridor to determine which words would think of the final system of formal review so things are definitely changing my feeling about the web as a whole is that it
Yes, it will change the structure of society because there are a lot of things that don't change.
One of the things that doesn't change is the capability of a human being.
We still can have so many relationships.
We can have so many connections with different people.
We can be interested in so many different areas.
We can read so many newspaper books in a certain time.
Each human being has got a certain capability to have, if you like, a certain
like an atom in a molecule to connect with so many different directions.
But the way it's done is it breaks down the barriers, but how do you choose those in different ways.
So the job we have now is how to rearrange ourselves, and each person has to think about how now I've got such a big choice of do I work.
I can work with somebody in Rhodesia about this project instead of somebody just next to me in Boston.
And how do I maximize my use of the system that I am in society under these situations?
And at the same time, institutions.
My feeling is very strongly that the solar structure of society has to have is fractal, that it has hail on different levels, like a coastline.
You look at a coastline from satellite, an incoming spaceship, I haven't done it personally, but I'm told in the picture that it looks pretty.
And then as you fly into aircraft level, it looks pretty still.
You see it at a different scale.
As you zoom in on this coastline, it has the same property that lots of natural systems have, like ferns, but as you zoom in,
is just as fascinating at every level.
And society tends to have that structure.
I think it's very important that it does have that structure.
So while there are some who would say, let's use the web, get rid of the institutions, and let's just have individual people all over, I feel that would be tremendously inefficient.
Similarly, those who say, the great thing about the web is it's allowed us to completely centralize all
They had to distribute the PCs, now they can put them all back on the mainframe again, and allow the people on the PCs to access them on the web.

So, in fact, people are very concerned about, they're worried about the heavens gate phenomenon, the very, very isolated cults occurring on the web, because you can limit who you cook very easily in email posts.
When you follow a link to a website, you only follow links that the person who's made from that website or other websites are staying with nature.
You can stay within a very narrow culture.
And similarly, at the same time, sometimes the same people are worried about that and worried about the McDonald's effect.
The fact that they feel, the French feel, that they open up high for America, increasing their bandwidth.
McDonald's will flood down.
I actually used that as an example once in a talk, and I went back to my hotel room and was there on both the folds of the USA today and pushed into the door.
There was a story about a French farmer who had actually driven up to a McDonald's being built near him.
chain around the building and pull it away with its back up.
This is real, but what society needs, in fact, it needs a balance.
It needs to be up there on every level.
So here we go.
Many men are working on the New England level.
You're probably involved in working on a little bit of a town.
Every now and again, you go to an international conference.
As a human being, you're working on different levels and you're helping the society have this practical nature.
So, an institution like a library has to sit there in the middle of it.
And it is, in my opinion, I think it is good to have some chunky, long-lived institutions.
And I think it's at the same time very important that they should be always challenged by the letter I. That there should be some larger writing ones and you shouldn't give them too much power.
What happens up now on the net is that when you have selection, there's business selection and endorsement of things.
which happens in very many different areas, or in very many different places as well, like newspapers, where a lot of information flows in, and some groups decide for all its values.
Just to it, it's high quality.
I see these things, there will be a diversification.
There's an interesting website, if we'd like, ePinions.com, or various of them, where you can go and the whole website exists by allowing people to cluster together and rate
for example, consumer products, and then rate each other's ideas, and basically build up little clusters of people who believe the same sort of thing.

I can imagine, and it's very interesting to imagine setting up a website which allows academics to do that, to rate each other's people very quickly, very efficiently, to build something moderated, not by a committee, but more basically by a program, which allows groups to become more and more important.
And if these groups rate each other, you can imagine a whole web
of different groups which endorse things and rate each other.
We get back to the 80-year-old questions of how does traditional science protect itself?

How do you make sure that there's a body of science which is not questioned and which you don't, you won't always be impacted by people telling you that UFOs are just, you know, break the rules of gravity or the gyroscopes break the rules of Newton's law of motion.
that we cut down that noise, that allow our children to learn things that we believe is good.
On the other hand, occasionally allow Einstein to come in and out to challenge.
And that would be accepted when he proved that, in fact, some of the traditional assumptions are wrong.
Same thing with libraries, that there will always be, I hope there will always be challenges.
And on the net, there will be websites, machines, which operate as a morale of endorphins.
And the important thing is that

The established community faces very, very strongly on the idea of putting together a long-lived community, a long-lived culture, and at the same time accept that there will be others all the time challenging it and realize that that is part of the process, realizing there will be newsgroups which in fact end up with a greater set of experts than conference.
What do you do then?

Then it becomes, in fact, more important to archive internet news groups than it does to archive the conference procedures, because that is where the creativity is happening, that's where the ideas are being put together.
That's where, if you want to find out what defines the field, that's where you go.
So it's very important to be able to recognize those things of switch.
It's important that, for example, you don't form a club of libraries across the world reject
any form of selection which is not from a member of the club.
Each library has got to be able to choose, interoperate, in a particular field, in a particular geographical area, the real social phenomena which are happening when it comes to selection.

And always, so each little group, I imagine each little group in a very organic way, with its own feeling about what, its own current feeling about what it feels to be, the fruits that it wishes to deserve.
always trying to find the best representation of that, but still, all we're not realizing is that everybody else is going to have different ideas, and those ideas are just a balance.

It's a really interesting balance between the chaos of allowing in any, any, any author who decides to put up about your library, and being stuck with one library which completely misses the next revolution.
So, I told you I was going to ask you questions instead of, uh,
I'll give you answers.
That is the requirement I put on it, that you should always be very accepting, and to work with all the other different, all these new upcoming things which challenge librarianship in a way.

ability to be, to look at yourself and your organization as part of the web, as connecting not just hierarchically with one master and with a lot of women, but in a very flexible way with different people in different directions.

Now, when it comes to preservation, so much of the selection, when it comes to preservation, I can tell you at a moment what I've seen, a lot of people, I've stopped somebody in the street, what do you think is the kind of problem with the web?

and you walk your way down through the catalogs.

coming over the country where you have these things under those sinks that you're not aware of.
